reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A Wonderful Surprise
reviews.reviewText: What feels like a completely open, honest look at the lives of Alva Vanderbilt and Caroline Astor. What started out as a readily embraced feud over time melded to respect and even friendship. A very interesting look at the outrageous lifestyles lived by the very rich, their striving to be at the top of the societal pyramid. Also a reminder that the parties, the balls, the clothing all were hiding the thing missing from their lives over which they had no control. The men controlled everything. The women had the social part of the relationship, used to enhance the value of the men they served. This book was well written and gave me a taste of The Four Hundred that I had never understood. They were real people. What different times those were. Maybe still are!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars The Social Graces of the Gilded Ages
reviews.reviewText: No matter what book you read about the so called Gilded Age, you will probably read more about the competition between Alva. Vanderbilt and Caroline Astor, their houses, clothing, events and how society regarded them. The author of this book ( Renee Rosen) has chosen to add some fiction between the facts to describe the competition between the two women and how it effected their personalities, their spouses, their families, friends and residential areas. The author also describes in detail how she wrote the book and questions for book clubs.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Very Good Reading
reviews.reviewText: I loved reading this book by Renee Rosen. All about the Vanderbilt’s and Astor’s during the gilded age.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Highly Readable, However......
reviews.reviewText: This was an interesting and educational read, very true to history. I recommend it. My only complaints are the huge gaps in time leaving us unaware of how certain storylines played out and the dialect was far too modern. That makes it easier for people to understand but she could have come closer to the vernacular of the time. But I've been accused of being a purist. Still, I recommend it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Overall a good book.
reviews.reviewText: I chose this rating because at points the book was really good but at times it felt chaotic. Somewhat all over the place and missing key details. Other than tht I enjoyed it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A very good book
reviews.reviewText: How the other half once lived is mind boggling! Women so subserviant it’s hard to imagine.Loved learning about “society” and how vital acceptance was the the super wealthy women of the day. Extravagance was the norm, yet their money didn’t bring happiness, or approval by the powers that be.Really enjoyed the book, and recommend it highly!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I enjoyed it very much much. Love reading about late 1800’s early 1900 and the people and what was happening then.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2022
reviews.reviewText: I have always been a bit obsessed with the Gilded Age and this story offered an excellent look inside the world of the wealthy (old and new money) in New York's Gilded Age. It was obvious Ms. Rosen had done her research, as the story spanned 3 decades. Both Mrs. Astor and Mrs. Vanderbilt saw a lot of tragedy in their lives. We don't often realize that when we hear the usual stories from that time. The story really transported me back to that era with the fashion descriptions and the peek into the daily life of the rich and famous. You can be sure things were extremely cutthroat then!! At first I was not sure I liked the "social character" but as I read, I realized it gave an even deeper look at the world at that time.
Ese libro lo compré para regalárselo a mi hijo
This book is amazing! A must read for anyone who loves the lifestyle of the rich and famous. Captivating storyline, I could not put the book down.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 22, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I so enjoyed this book which I stumbled on quite by accident via the The Newport Preservation Society. It opens the door onto a world which is within touching distance of our own but which was so very different. I loved the character portrayals which are rooted in history but have fictional stories woven around them. Excellent insight into the Gilded Age.
I love that this is based on real people and real events. Renee has a flair to give the story life.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 16, 2021
reviews.reviewText: I like historical books that are set in particular periods. This one highlighted the position of women in the late 19th and early 20th century in New York. It's based on real characters who are well known and tells you a lot about them and their families. I found it an interesting contrast to the books of Edith Wharton from an earlier era. The position of women hadn't changed as much as one might have thought.
